intro.description: These few steps will familiarise you with the ASSET user interface and general processes involved with creating a simulation. In an earlier cheat sheet you should have created an empty project, and in there you provided a link to the sample ASSET data.

item.title: Checking you have some data
item.description: In an earlier cheat sheet you should have created an empty project and linked in the sample ASSET data. If you didn't, then frankly you're buggered - so if I was you I'd go back and do it right now.

item.title: ASSET data files
item.description: ASSET breaks down the information required to run through a scenario into two separate file types: scenario files describe what's to be simulated, and control files direct ASSET in how to run the simulation. Whilst both types of file contain data stored in the textual xml data format, the ASSET working practice is that scenario files have the .asset file suffix (to help you to organise your data)

item.title: ASSET modelling process
item.description: The process you'll follow when using ASSET will be as follows: 1 define your scenario, 2 specify how the senario will be controlled, 3 load the datafiles, 4 run through the scenario, 5 analyse the scenario results.

item.title: Open a scenario file
item.description: Right, let's start off with a scenario file. Double-click on the ForceProt.asset data file in the AssetData folder of your navigator. It will open in the central editor pane.

item.title: The ASSET XML editor
item.description: ASSET's xml editor uses a two-tab construct. At the foot of the editor pane you'll see two tabs, one named Design and the other named Source. The Design tab is a tree-oriented editor that gives you an overview of your scenario, the Source tab lets you get right down in the weeds.

item.title: Have a look at the scenario
item.description: In the Design view, you'll see that the top-level element in our tree is the Scenario, and this contains child elements that specify the time-step, the environment used for the simulation, and the participants in the simulation. In xml, these data structures are called elements, they're annotated in the design view with an e symbol. Data items in these elements are called attributes - which are annotated with a b symbol. To the right of the participants element you'll see some green text that specifies what types of element can be added to the participants element - in this case the list of platform types that can be specified. If you right-click on the Participants element and select Add Child you'll see a list of platform types that can be added - but we'll leave that for later. Open the participants element by clicking on the triangle to the left of it, and you'll see it contains three surface vessels and a single ssk. Open the first surface vessel and you'll see it's called HVU. Attributes are edited with the Properties view. Open this using the Window/Show View/Properties menu, or by clicking the Click to perform button below. Next, feel free to browse through the HVU child elements to view the data structures.

item.title: View a control file
item.description:
Ok, close the scenario file by clicking on the x symbol in the tab above it. Now, double-click on ForceProt.xml. When this opens you'll see it's a ScenarioController element that contains two children, a ScenarioGenerator (that describes how random variances should be applied to your scenario), plus an ObserverList that defines a series of control structures that listen to your running scenario - recording observations to file or interacting with the scenario itself.
If you look into the ScenarioGenerator object you'll see it contains an element that defines multiple participants - 300 of the vessel named SSK. It also varies their initial course, and where they start.
If you open the ObserverList you'll see it contains 6 observers that control how long the scenario runs for, producing a track plot image, producing Debrief plot files, plus indications of how to display/control detections.ctions.ons.

item.title: Open the scenario controller
item.description: For the next step you'll need the Scenario Controller view open - so do that using the Window/Show view menu, or by clicking on the Click to perform button below.

item.title: Load the data
item.description: Now, drag the two ForceProt files onto the Data files area at the top of the Scenario Controller view. It may take a few seconds to load - because ASSET is generating 300 random SSKs, as requested in the control file. You'll see panel update to show the file names. In the table in the lower-half of the view the scenario has been added - with a status of Waiting. The columns to the right-hand side of the table show the current value of any assigned observers that are capable of providing a running commentary.

item.title: Run the scenario
item.description: Right, now to run the scenario. Well, before we run the scenario we have to tie in the observers to the scenario. Do this by clicking on the Init button in the Selected scenario area of the scenario controller. After the scenario has initialised the Play and Step buttons will become enabled. Click on the Step button a few times, and you'll see the scenario time (green text on black background) move forward. Then click on Play and the scenario will run through to completion. It may take a few minutes - we've created 300 target vessels remember.

item.title: Watch the scenario
item.description: Were you expecting a little more graphic detail? Ok. Before we do, we will restart the scenario. Do this by first clicking on the Reload data files yellow-arrows icon in the mini toolbar at the top of the scenario controller. Now re-do the Init for the scenario, and lastly click on the globe icon in the mini-toolbar. Your plot should now open, showing a spread of red ssk icons across the screen, with the random courses we specified in the control file. Click on the Step button a few times and you'll see the scenario move forward. Click on Play and you'll see it move forward. It will take 2 minutes or so to complete, but not too long.

item.title: What can we analyse?
item.description: Right, it's finally finished running. What do you do now? That's it, you do some analysis. If you look in your Navigator pane, you'll see a ForceProt folder (this was the folder name specified in the control file). Have a look in there and you'll see a .rep and a .png file. Double-click on the png to open it, and you'll see a snapshot. You could alternatively double-click on the rep file to open it in the Debrief editor, though I wouldn't recommend it in this case because it contains soooo many tracks.
